html:
@TheJaredWilcurt there are very practical problems we are trying to solve as per the blog post. I mean just yesterday we sat down with someone who wasn't familiar with Gitter with the current/old UI and they experienced pretty conceptual problems understanding how their community could have more than just one room and when people arrive at the community, how to discover those additional rooms and they felt their community didn't have a "home" inside of Gitter and that it's just a large collection of single chat rooms.

More and more we are seeing these larger communities growing and we've tried various experiments within the old UI to try and surface this better without much success.

I'm not here to defend it, i'm here to rationalise why we are making the changes and to come to a good place that balances out some of the problems we are trying to address with making it a good experience for all.

for instance, if the All Conversations view behaved exactly like the current menu, would it (whatever it is, because you still haven't articulated it) solve your issues or not?
text:
@TheJaredWilcurt there are very practical problems we are trying to solve as per the blog post. I mean just yesterday we sat down with someone who wasn't familiar with Gitter with the current/old UI and they experienced pretty conceptual problems understanding how their community could have more than just one room and when people arrive at the community, how to discover those additional rooms and they felt their community didn't have a "home" inside of Gitter and that it's just a large collection of single chat rooms.

More and more we are seeing these larger communities growing and we've tried various experiments within the old UI to try and surface this better without much success. 

I'm not here to defend it,  i'm here to rationalise why we are making the changes and to come to a good place that balances out some of the problems we are trying to address with making it a good experience for all.

for instance, if the All Conversations view behaved **exactly** like the current menu, would it (whatever it is, because you still haven't articulated it) solve your issues or not?

text:
My recommendations regarding the left menu (sorry if I'm repeating something, haven't followed the conversations here) : 
- Collapse by default 'All rooms' and 'your suggestions' (I don't really need any of those)
- In some cases I have only one chatroom and I have to click on the left menu, and then click again in the chatroom to enter. That's one click more than before, it should somehow enter immediatly although I see that in cases where I have more than one channel probably wouldn't be the best option (in that case I would choose *enter immediatly to the first chatroom in the list*) 
- The left menu looks really awesome, but there's too much space not being used, I can't think of any use though

Hello, thought I'd drop in and offer my $0.02 on the new design. I guess I'm ok with it, other than the following:
1) The collapse button is way too hard to notice. Took me a while before I even realised it was there.
2) The background colour is WAAAY too intense and really tries to be the hero, instead of the UI it's supposed to be promoting. The icons and other interface elements should not be having to compete with the background for attention. Yes, it looks "pretty" and all, but there's a reason we don't use tiling textures behind webpage content in this day and age. The content and UI should be king, not the sidebar background. I'd make it a subtle flat colour, inline with your existing colour scheme.
3) I found it annoying that my favourites aren't at the top anymore, and that to see my favourites, I have to opt out of seeing the other rooms in the list as well. I'm being made to click extra times, unnecessarily.

There is absolutly a need to hide the left ribbon with icons, not just the chat room list. In fact, chat list is useful, the ribbon less so. It takes up space and shifts conversation to the right. Sadly, I don't like it so far and really hope, that I can hide the ribbon with icons, instead of a chat room list ... or both ...

What you are fighting guys, is the insufficient initial design decision in the first place. Coming from Rebol ecosystem, we use an AltME app for some 15 yers or so. Communities are definitely isolated. In AltME, we have so called Worlds. Those worlds collect private messages as well as chat rooms (groups). World owner can decide, who gets in, groups can be private/hidden, only for selected ppl, etc. Glad that you are improving on that aspect though ...

html:
I wonder if it would make sense to create virtual chat rooms, either public or personal.

In virtual rooms users/owners would be able to subscribe to different real chat rooms. The conversations of all subscribed rooms would appear in the virtual room. Similar to an aggregator of rooms if you like. The name of the real room could prepend the user name in the conversation thread. Responding to someone from a virtual room would require to select the name of the real room you're responding to but auto-completion could greatly help for the purpose.

For example, one could create a public virtual room called "web development". The owner coud "link" this virtual room to other real rooms like well-known JS frameworks, collaborative books about CSS/JS, etc. This could enable more domain oriented rooms.

The maintainer of a framework project could create a virtual room linked to all the channels related to his software and the important libraries the code relies to.

Another example. A user could create a personal virtual room for all the projects he is actually involved in. This would reduce the pain of switching of rooms all the time.
text:
I wonder if it would make sense to create virtual chat rooms, either public or personal.

In virtual rooms users/owners would be able to subscribe to different real chat rooms. The conversations of all subscribed rooms would appear in the virtual room. Similar to an aggregator of rooms if you like. The name of the real room could prepend the user name in the conversation thread. Responding to someone from a virtual room would require to select the name of the real room you're responding to but auto-completion could greatly help for the purpose.

For example, one could create a public virtual room called "web development". The owner coud "link" this virtual room to other real rooms like well-known JS frameworks, collaborative books about CSS/JS, etc. This could enable more *domain oriented* rooms.

The maintainer of a framework project could create a virtual room linked to all the channels related to his software and the important libraries the code relies to.

Another example. A user could create a personal virtual room for all the projects he is actually involved in. This would reduce the pain of switching of rooms all the time.

I would go with: 

**Lite** *mode*

- a button for the menu, one for the list of rooms, the bar with the room title and the 3 icons from the top-right

**Default / Normal** *mode* 

- like now, but with collapsible pannels

**Cusom** *mode*

- where we can have our own CSS inserted.

text:
Also, maintainability. One thing is when you need to navigate through 5+ divs just to get to the next message in line, using the code inspector, and, overall, more code means higher chances of it being more difficult to understand.

Also, I am sorry if seem or am rude, it is and was not my intention.
What I'm trying to do is have custom CSS (thrugh Stylish), but with a quick look at the code, I can see that there is a lot of stuff which I don't find useful.

html:
For example, right click on an message in this chat and try to navigate to it. You will find that it will take over a minute, and when you get to a message, instead of having the text in a span and the avatar as an image, it's another div. Sure, the class differentiate, but I do not get why should one be using divs over something native. Sure, you can stil use the class, but you don't need to insert it as a background.

Also, if you're concerned with the load time of the images, why not use a .gif with a 1x1px size as a background and lazy-load the images by changing their SRC with JS?
text:
For example, right click on an message in this chat and try to navigate to it. You will find that it will take over a minute, and when you get to a message, instead of having the text in a span and the avatar as an image, it's another div. Sure, the class differentiate, but I do not get  why should one be using divs over something native. Sure, you can stil use the class, but you don't need to insert it as a background. 

Also, if you're concerned with the load time of the images, why not use a .gif with a 1x1px size as a background and lazy-load the images by changing their SRC with JS?

html:
Or you could leave the messages without a image, but padding to the left, and after the whole document is loaded, load another CSS to insert the images.

I'm not trying to be a douche, but I simply cannot wrap my head around it...
I mean, I get if the answer is the lack of time, or too much refactoring to do, but I would still like to know the reason...
text:
Or you could leave the messages without a image, but padding to the left, and after the whole document is loaded, load another CSS to insert the images. 

I'm not trying to be a douche, but I simply cannot wrap my head around it...
I mean, I get if the answer is the lack of time, or too much refactoring to do, but I would still like to know the reason...

text: @sapioit As discussed before, we have thought about adding a few variations to choose from but we have no intention of allowing users to add their own custom CSS. You can do it yourself with Stylish as you mentioned.

html:
@tommoor the search searches rooms+people+messages. previously we had the opposite problem where people didn't know where to search for rooms because the search was on the right in the context of a room.

cross room message search will be coming later in the year - along with a few other things, so having a universal search on the left makes sense.
text:
@tommoor the search searches rooms+people+messages. previously we had the opposite problem where people didn't know where to search for rooms because the search was on the right in the context of a room.

cross room message search will be coming later in the year - along with a few other things, so having a universal search on the left makes sense.

html: i also mention, specifically, a few other things, because you'll see some additional changes in the future (like structured discussions in addition to chat) that will make communities much broader than just a single chat room.
text: i also mention, specifically, a few other things, because you'll see some additional changes in the future (like structured discussions in addition to chat) that will make communities much broader than just a single chat room.

html: @sapioit there's a lot of legacy in some of our dom structure that dates back many years and it's exactly that, a function of time and the other priorities we have to focus on. we'd love to revisit the html/css structure later in the year. there's also some structure that exists as a result of the ui framework we use (marionette) that can also be optimised.
text: @sapioit there's a lot of legacy in some of our dom structure that dates back many years and it's exactly that, a function of time and the other priorities we have to focus on. we'd love to revisit the html/css structure later in the year.  there's also some structure that exists as a result of the ui framework we use (marionette) that can also be optimised.

html: and a lot of the html structure was built before we had any dedicated front-end developers - so built by more traditional backend devs who didn't neccessarily have a good understanding of the nuances of more modern html structures
text: and a lot of the html structure was built before we had any dedicated front-end developers - so built by more traditional backend devs who didn't neccessarily have a good understanding of the nuances of more modern html structures
